body: I think there was general consensus at the [last TSC meeting](https://github.com/eslint/tsc-meetings/blob/db3c0010144ba403a95daf3611af24ee271b3c78/notes/2018/2018-03-01.md#planning-for-500-release) that we should drop support for Node 4 in our next major release. We will probably start doing prereleases for it sometime in the next few weeks.

issue.title: Breaking: drop supporting Node.js 4 (fixes #10052)

labels.name: build
labels.description: This change relates to ESLint's build process

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: There is consensus among the team that this change meets the criteria for inclusion

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

issue.body:
<!--
    ESLint adheres to the [JS Foundation Code of Conduct](https://js.foundation/community/code-of-conduct).
-->
refs: #10052  
**What is the purpose of this pull request? (put an "X" next to item)**


<!--
    Please ensure your pull request is ready:

    - Read the pull request guide (https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/pull-requests)
    - Include tests for this change
    - Update documentation for this change (if appropriate)
-->

<!--
    The following is required for all pull requests:
-->

**What changes did you make? (Give an overview)**
updated required Node.js version to 6+, and removed 4, 5, 7 in travis.

**Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?**
should we also remove Node 7?

body: You might want to consider requiring Node.js 6.5. It has a newer V8 version and a better coverage of ES2015 features, mostly around edge cases.

I'll move [this TSC agenda item](https://github.com/eslint/tsc-meetings/issues/81#issuecomment-377360664) to this issue.

**TSC Summary**: We need to decide which versions of Node we will support in the next major release.
**TSC Questions**:

* Should we explicitly drop support for Node 7?
* Should we support anything above a particular version of Node 6 (e.g. >=6.9.4), or any version of Node 6 at all (i.e. >=6.0.0)?

My opinion is that we should drop support for Node 7, and support `^6.14.0`, `^8.11.0`, and `>=9.10.0` (currently the latest versions on each release line). There are a few reasons for this:

* The latest version of Node 6 has some features that are neither available on Node 7 nor on earlier versions of Node 6. It would be nice if we could use those features if we need them during the ESLint v5.x lifespan.
* Earlier versions of Node 6 (as well as 8, 9, and the latest version of Node 7) have known security vulnerabilities. As a result, I think most users will be using the latest version on their release line (e.g. `6.14.0`), or they should be able to upgrade without too much difficulty. It seems unnecessary to prevent ourselves from using a set of features just to accommodate users who are using versions of Node with security vulnerabilities.
* Earlier versions of Node have known bugs which are fixed in later versions. If we officially supported outdated versions, then ostensibly we might need to work around a bug so that ESLint would work on versions of Node with that bug. This seems silly; a better solution would be for the user to upgrade their Node version so that the bug is fixed.
* Due to the way Travis works, we only run our tests on the latest version from each release line anyway. Even if we officially support Node 6.0.0, it will be difficult to make sure ESLint continues to work on that version without remembering when each Node feature was introduced.

I looked through Node's changelogs and created a list of features that have been added to recent versions of the Node 6 release line. I omitted some features (e.g. relating to cryptography) which seem like they are unlikely to be used by ESLint in the future.

<details>
<summary>Features in Node 6.13.0 which are not in Node 7</summary>

* `console.count()`
* `console.clear()`
* `Module.builtinModules`
* `process.ppid`
* `assert.fail()` can take one or two arguments

</details>

<details>
<summary>Features in Node 6.13.0 which are not in Node 6.0.0</summary>

* (all of the features from the above list)
* `NODE_NO_WARNINGS `environment variable
* `util.inspect` supports `%i` and `%f` specifiers
* `util.inspect.custom` symbol
* ES6 iterator closing
* ES6 `ArrayBuffer`s have correct prototype chains
* `Symbol.species`, `Symbol.hasInstance`, `Symbol.match` on strings
* Function `.name` property for object methods
* `RegExp.prototype.flags`
* Array iterators have the correct prototype chain
* Correct method behavior for subclassed arrays 

</details>

---

I don't think we have an immediate need for any of these features, but I can think of many plausible future scenarios where they would be nice to have.

Do we plan to enforce this somehow? I remember when we initially released eslint 3.0 it didn't include any node4-only feature in the critical path and caused some confusion when we added it later on, so I think it would be better if we did it right away

According to the [npm docs](https://docs.npmjs.com/files/package.json#engines), if we update the `engines` field in `package.json`, npm will produce a warning if the user has an outdated version of Node.

If we want to do more than that, I can think of a few options:

* Add a runtime check in `bin/eslint.js` to check the Node version and print a warning if the version is too low
* Add some Node 6 syntax on the critical path somewhere

The former could be nice for UX, but it would require us to keep `bin/eslint.js` parseable indefinitely on old versions of Node. I can definitely think of some places on the critical path where Node 6 syntax would be nice, so we could do that anyway.

@alberto Agreed. I think we could potentially leverage a package like [check-node-version](https://github.com/parshap/check-node-version) in order to avoid having to really maintain that logic ourselves.

I'm not strongly opposed to it, but I'm a bit averse to the "runtime check" option because it would hurt performance, and this can be detected statically (the user should have already seen a warning message from npm).

It seems like there are two potential issues here:

* The user might be confused about why ESLint is suddenly broken after upgrading to ESLint 5.
* The user might upgrade to ESLint 5.0.0 and have it work initially when using Node 4, but then have it break when (e.g.) ESLint 5.0.1 is released and uses Node 6 syntax somewhere.

It seems like the npm `engines` check already handles the first problem. If I'm understanding correctly, the issue with the ESLint 3.0 release was along the lines of the second problem. It seems like we could avoid this by making sure we use destructuring (or some other Node 6 syntax/feature) right from the start.

https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/10052#issuecomment-377381218 has a :+1: from a majority of TSC members, so I'm going to update #10074 to change the supported versions to `^6.14.0`, `^8.11.0`, and `>=9.10.0`, and remove this issue from the TSC agenda.

Personally I think this should wait a bit longer for merge, since neither @ilyavolodin nor @nzakas have seen this discussion yet and they have been key drivers of our past policy in this area. The last thing we want to do is merge with a later :-1: from them. (Of course, the rest of the TSC should get a chance to see this as well.)

Ok, I'll re-add it to the TSC agenda and mark the corresponding PR as `evaluating`. I think the only time-sensitive question would be whether we want the change that updates our Node support to go into tomorrow's prerelease, but I suppose it would be fine to leave it for now and make that change in a future prerelease.
While eslint probably isnt used too often on AWS lambda, it might be nice to continue to support it. The newest Node.js version supported by AWS Lambda is 6.10.3.

@realityking Thanks for that info. My gut reaction is that AWS Lambda should update to a version of Node without known security vulnerabilities, but I realize this isn't something that users have control over. How often do they generally update?
